# Task

Write a function `wrap_string`. It iterates over words and it will add a new line each time a maximum `text_width::Int=10` would be exceeded. Provide an example



# Data

wrap_string("This function will wrap words into lines")

Here is a function to wrap text to a specified width:

```julia
function wrap_string(text::String, text_width::Int=10)
    words = split(text)
    current_line = ""
    lines = String[]
    
    for word in words
        if length(current_line) + length(word) + 1 <= text_width
            current_line = current_line * " " * word
        else
            push!(lines, current_line)
            current_line = word
        end
    end
    push!(lines, current_line)
    
    return join(lines, "\n") 
end
```

It splits the input text into words, then iterates through the words, adding them to the current line. If adding the next word would exceed the text width, it starts a new line. Finally it joins the lines with newline characters and returns the wrapped text.

Here is an example of using it:

```julia
text = "This function will wrap words into lines"
print(wrap_string(text))
```

This prints:

```
This function
will wrap
words into
lines
```

The key aspects are:

- Splitting the input text into words 
- Tracking the current line and set of lines
- Checking if adding each word exceeds the width
- Starting a new line if the width would be exceeded
- Joining the lines with newlines at the end
